claim: If you swallow gum, nothing will happen to you.

supporting.text: Gum is indigestible but passes harmlessly through the digestive system, as it is not broken down by stomach acids.

attacks.text: Gum is indigestible but passes harmlessly through the digestive system, as it is not broken down by stomach acids.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require swallowing very large quantities.
Some people may experience mild digestive discomfort after swallowing gum, such as bloating or nausea.
Digestive discomfort from gum is temporary and resolves on its own without medical intervention.

supporting.text: Medical sources, such as the Mayo Clinic, confirm that swallowed gum is excreted in stool without causing blockages in healthy individuals.

attacks.text: Medical sources, such as the Mayo Clinic, confirm that swallowed gum is excreted in stool without causing blockages in healthy individuals.
While gum is usually excreted, rare cases of intestinal blockages have been reported in children who swallowed large amounts of gum.
The reported cases of blockages involved pre-existing digestive conditions or extremely large quantities of gum, not typical single-swallow scenarios.
Gum may accumulate in the digestive tract over time if swallowed regularly, potentially causing issues.
The human digestive system is capable of passing small foreign objects regularly without accumulation.

supporting.text: The human digestive tract is designed to move indigestible materials through peristalsis, ensuring gum does not accumulate.

attacks.text: The human digestive tract is designed to move indigestible materials through peristalsis, ensuring gum does not accumulate.
While peristalsis moves materials, gum can stick to the intestinal walls in rare cases, potentially causing blockages.
Medical studies show that intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and usually involve swallowing large quantities.
Gum contains synthetic polymers that resist digestion, unlike other indigestible materials like fiber.
Even synthetic polymers in gum are mechanically broken down and expelled by the digestive system over time.

supporting.text: There is no documented evidence of gum causing long-term harm when swallowed in typical quantities (1-2 pieces).

attacks.text: There is no documented evidence of gum causing long-term harm when swallowed in typical quantities (1-2 pieces).
Swallowed gum can accumulate in the digestive tract over time, potentially causing blockages, especially in children.
Cases of gum-related blockages are extremely rare and usually involve swallowing large amounts of gum in a short period.
Gum is indigestible and may stick to the intestinal lining, causing discomfort or temporary digestive issues.
The human digestive system is capable of passing indigestible materials like gum without issues in most cases.

supporting.text: Pediatric guidelines state that accidental gum ingestion in children is not a medical concern unless excessive amounts are consumed.

attacks.text: Pediatric guidelines state that accidental gum ingestion in children is not a medical concern unless excessive amounts are consumed.
Excessive gum ingestion can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children with smaller digestive tracts.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require very large quantities to occur.
Some individuals may have pre-existing digestive conditions that make even small amounts of swallowed gum problematic.
Medical guidelines account for average cases and already exclude rare pre-existing conditions from general recommendations.
